messageBody:
Quoth Chappell, Simon P:
[...]
> I think that, for me, it's partly a matter of "rightness" and the
> rest is reporting. The "rightness" is that it is the Right Thing
> To Do(tm) to throw a IAE when receiving junk parameters. [...]

*chuckle* I'll so stipulate, though I notice that the existing
Java API doesn't do so in all cases. (I don't mean to refer only
to its throwing NullPtrExc when arguments are unexpectedly null as
others have noted, but also, eg., to its throwing
IndexOutOfBoundsExc from String.charAt(), and ArithmeticExc from
BigInteger.divide().)

> [...] In your
> code fragment, the different things that I might do would be to
> issue different errors to the user or log file. An IAE means that
> the programmer goofed, while other errors might be for less
> negligent reasons.
>
> For example, if my code is reading a file from a CD and someone
> ejects the CD during the process [...]

Yes, but surely that would look like
try {
// Do something involving that file
} catch (CDNotInDriveException e) {
// (a little-known subclass of IOException)
// ... foo! tell user to put the CD back in
} catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
// ... which still leaves me puzzled about what goes here ...
} catch (RuntimeException e) {
// ... without being equally good here
}

To put it another way:

Certainly IllegalArgExc means that the programmer goofed, so there
is almost certainly no possibility of fixing the problem at
runtime (as by asking the user to do something, or retrying the
operation). The program just has to accept that the operation
that threw the exception cannot proceed (and possibly invoke
fallback mechanisms, make entries in a log, apologize abjectly to
the user, etc.).

But this applies equally for *any* unanticipated RuntimeExc, and
so can be done generically by catching RuntimeExc... at which
point it doesn't matter whether IllegalArgExc or NullPtrExc or
IndexOutOfBoundsExc was thrown.

(To be clear: I'm willing to agree that IllegalArgExc is more
informative than NullPtrExc to a human reading it in a stack trace
or log, and is on these grounds preferable where appropriate. I'm
just saying that I can't imagine running code having any use for
the distinction... except, conceivably, the code of a debugger.)
